msContents.summary: 1 copy of Shajarat al-as̲mār by ʿAlá Munajjim

note.p: An early Persian treatise on astrology, also known as Ashjār va asmār or Asmār va ashjār. It was written in 686-7/1287-8 by ‘Alā’-i Munajjim, ‘Alī-Shāh ibn Muḥammad Khwārazmī Bukhārī for the Īlkhān’s vizier, Shams al-Dīn Muḥammad ibn Sayf al-Dīn Aḥmad-Shāh.

The work comprises sections, called shajara (tree), each comprising several chapters called shu‘ba (branch). For further details, see PL II/1, pp. 62-63. A lithographed edition was published at Lucknow in 1903 under the title Samara-’i shajara-’i nujūm. For other manuscripts, see FNKhF I, pp. 236-238 (33 copies listed). The present manuscript is one of the six earliest copies.

Begins: Basmala Ḥamd va sanā Āfarīdgārī-rā ki aflāk-i davāyir va nujūm-i savāyir bayāfrīd va shukr va sipās Vājib al-Vujūdī-rā ki ‘anāṣir va arkān dar vujūd āvard va az āsār-i ‘ulviyyāt va ta’sīr-i sufliyyāt mazjhā sākht
Ends: Ammā rūzgār vafā nakard pas barīn khatm kard Agarchi khwud-rā dar sadad-i muṣannifān nadānist nishāna’ī sākht va az Khudā-yi ta‘ālā tawfīq khwāst ba-sākhtan-i ū. Va Llāh Valī al-tawfīq

Other contents: front endpaper, title statement, one verse bayt and one rubā‘ī; 1r, excerpts from a work (or works) on astrology, owners’ inscriptions (one being dated 1120/1708-9) and seal impressions; 2r, Ottoman inscription and seal impression of ‘Usmān Bayg; marginal corrections throughout, written by the copyist and by others; additions in margins, 44v-47r, 62v-63r and sporadically elsewhere; 158v, notes in Arabic, concerning conjunctions of the planets, etc., in relation to the date of events in Islamic history; back endpaper, the formula Mā shā’ Allāh lā ḥawla wa lā quvvata illā bi-Llāh.
Colophon, f. 158r; no name, date or place are mentioned. This copy probably dates from the 9th/15th century.

Very neat small naskhī. 19 lines. Red headings and diagrams. Good cream paper, discoloured to light beige towards the edges. 158 folios. 170 x 129 mm.; text lines 113 x 76 mm. Brown morocco binding, probably Ottoman; boards faced with marbled paper.

history.origin: 15th century Ottoman Empire Iran or Anatolia
